G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody and parenting time for the parties’ minor child under G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s prior judgment entered on May 14, 2019.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody and parenting time for the parties’ minor child under G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the Court’s prior judgment entered on May 14, 2019.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue in the Middlesex Division of the Probate and Family Court is proper pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 3, because the existing judgment was entered here and the child resides within this county.

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the safety and best interests of the minor child, as required by G.L. c. 208, § 28 and cases such as *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); and *Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2006) (Rule 1:28).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a substantial and material change of circumstances affecting the safety and best interests of a minor child under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Schuler does recite the general "material change of circumstances" standard for modification, but the case is about alimony and child support amounts, not about a post-judgment change in circumstances affecting a child’s safety or best interests specifically. It therefore supports only the generic change-of-circumstances requirement, not the more specific safety/best-interests aspect claimed in the proposition.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. Resolution of the issue rests in the judge’s sound discretion. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28…”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the safety and best interests of the minor child, as required by G.L. c. 208, § 28 and cases such as *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); and *Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2006) (Rule 1:28).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard concerns the standards and findings required for an initial custody determination, focusing on the child’s best interests under G.L. c. 208, § 31. It does not address the statutory requirement of a ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ necessary to modify an existing judgment under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Thus, it supports the best‑interests standard, not the change‑in‑circumstances proposition for post‑judgment modification.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. A.raw_text: *Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2006) (Rule 1:28)
*Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. A.proposition: Since entry of the 2019 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the safety and best interests of the minor child, as required by G.L. c. 208, § 28 and cases such as *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981); and *Mussa v. Mass. Trial Court*, 66 Mass. App. Ct. 1116 (2006) (Rule 1:28).

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The combination of Father’s progressive neurological condition, his documented falls, the medical instructions limiting his ability to be alone with the child in certain settings, and his continued insistence on an unchanged 50/50 schedule constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the child’s safety and welfare, within the meaning of *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case addressing the standard for authorizing removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 when parents share joint physical and legal custody. It does not involve or discuss a parent’s progressive medical condition, falls, safety-related medical instructions, or modification of a parenting schedule based on a substantial and material change in circumstances. The opinion’s ‘change in circumstances’ discussion is limited to relocation as a substantial change, not to health-based safety concerns or 50/50 schedules, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgment of divorce]….”
… “(4)(c) If neither parent has been exercising a clear majority of custodial responsibility for the child, the court should modify the plan… in accordance with the child’s best interests, taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The combination of Father’s progressive neurological condition, his documented falls, the medical instructions limiting his ability to be alone with the child in certain settings, and his continued insistence on an unchanged 50/50 schedule constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the child’s safety and welfare, within the meaning of *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn does not concern a parent’s progressive medical condition, physical limitations, or modification of a parenting schedule based on new health-related risks. It addresses domestic violence and the requirement that probate judges make explicit findings on the impact of such violence on the child and on custody determinations. While it emphasizes that risks to a child’s safety and welfare must be expressly considered, it does not analyze what constitutes a ‘substantial and material change in circumstances’ in the Mason v. Coleman sense, nor does it involve a change in circumstances arising from a parent’s deteriorating health or insistence on a 50/50 schedule despite medical limits.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The combination of Father’s progressive neurological condition, his documented falls, the medical instructions limiting his ability to be alone with the child in certain settings, and his continued insistence on an unchanged 50/50 schedule constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the child’s safety and welfare, within the meaning of *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); and *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde v. Rolde addresses initial custody and visitation determinations and the appropriateness of joint custody, not modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The opinion contains no discussion of changed medical conditions, safety risks arising after an existing order, or the Mason/Custody of Vaughn ‘material change’ framework, which post-dates Rolde. Thus, while Rolde is relevant to best-interests analysis and limiting visitation, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that such a medical deterioration and safety concern constitutes a substantial and material change in circumstances warranting modification.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The husband argues that the judge erred in awarding sole custody to the wife… However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence… From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that… the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation…”

*Granata v. Granata*, 91 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The circumstances now facing Samantha were not contemplated by the parties or the Court at the time of the 2019 Judgment and could not reasonably have been anticipated, satisfying the standard for modification articulated in *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981) and *Granata v. Granata*, 91 Mass. App. Ct. 362 (2017).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in Massachusetts removal cases under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the words “upon cause shown” mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child, and it repeatedly describes the best interests of the children as the central and paramount concern. While the case is focused on removal rather than general custody, it frames the entire analysis—both custody and removal—around the best‑interests standard, thereby supporting the broader proposition that the child’s best interests are the paramount consideration in such determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses the “best interests of the child” as the governing standard in Massachusetts custody determinations and traces its historical and doctrinal roots, citing prior Massachusetts cases including Yannas. The court states that in custody matters the touchstone inquiry is what is best for the child, and it reviews the judge’s decision under that standard. This directly supports the proposition that the paramount consideration in custody and parenting‑time determinations under Massachusetts law is the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting‑time determination is the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); and *Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).
*Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal sentencing/statutory-construction case about whether G.L. c. 265, § 18C allows a probationary sentence for armed home invasion. It does not concern custody, parenting time, family law, or the best interests of the child standard, nor does it cite or discuss G.L. c. 208, § 31, Yannas, or Custody of Kali. Therefore it does not provide any authority for the proposition about the paramount consideration in custody determinations.
*Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 530 (2009).relevant_excerpt:
We again invite the Legislature to clarify G. L. c. 265, § 18C.

The case is remanded to the county court for the entry of a judgment dismissing the Commonwealth’s petition under G. L. c. 211, § 3.

So ordered.

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: In assessing the child’s best interests, the Court must consider the child’s safety, emotional well‑being, stability, and the capacity of each parent to provide appropriate care, guidance, and a secure environment. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843‑44.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the ultimate question as determining the child’s “best interests” and explains that this involves evaluating stability, the impact of transitions, emotional attachments, and the relative capacities of the competing caretakers to meet Hugo’s special developmental needs and provide a suitable home. Although the case does not enumerate the best‑interests factors in the exact terms of the proposition or cite G.L. c. 208, § 31 (a divorce‑custody statute), its reasoning clearly relies on safety, emotional well‑being, stability, and each caregiver’s ability to provide appropriate care and support. Thus it functionally supports the stated best‑interests principle, even if the statutory citation is slightly mismatched.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development… [T]he judge appropriately considered the personal, educational, psychological, and other support available to each prospective parent to address Hugo’s needs.”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843\u201.proposition: In assessing the child’s best interests, the Court must consider the child’s safety, emotional well‑being, stability, and the capacity of each parent to provide appropriate care, guidance, and a secure environment. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 843‑44.

*Custody of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 595 (198.proposition: While Father’s diagnosis and physical limitations do not, by themselves, disqualify him from parenting, the practical impact of his condition on his ability to safely manage the child’s day‑to‑day care—particularly in emergency or physically demanding situations—must be weighed under the best‑interests standard. See *Custody of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 595 (1981); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007).
*Custody of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 595 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns parental unfitness and psychological incompatibility between mother and child; it does not address a parent’s diagnosis, physical disability, or physical limitations in providing care. The court’s analysis focuses on emotional/psychological harm and the child’s preferences, not on weighing a parent’s medical condition or physical capacity to handle emergencies. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the specific principle that a parent’s diagnosis and physical limitations must be evaluated for their practical impact on day-to-day care under the best-interests standard.
*Custody of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 595 (198.relevant_excerpt: “A finding of parental unfitness may be predicated on the circumstances within a particular family, as they adversely affect the particular child, without regard to the general quality of parental conduct per se. ‘It is not the quality or character of parental conduct per se that justifies State intervention on behalf of an abused, neglected, or otherwise endangered child. Rather, it is the fact of the endangerment itself.’”

*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..proposition: While Father’s diagnosis and physical limitations do not, by themselves, disqualify him from parenting, the practical impact of his condition on his ability to safely manage the child’s day‑to‑day care—particularly in emergency or physically demanding situations—must be weighed under the best‑interests standard. See *Custody of a Minor*, 383 Mass. 595 (1981); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007).
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses parental fitness and best interests in terms of bonding, length of separation from the guardian, and the psychological impact of changing custody, but it does not address a parent's medical diagnosis, physical limitations, or their effect on handling emergencies or physically demanding childcare. Its core holding is that fitness and best interests are interrelated and must be evaluated in light of the child’s existing attachments, not that physical or medical impairments must be weighed as described in the proposition. Therefore, using Guardianship of Estelle for that specific medical‑limitations proposition overstates and mischaracterizes what the case actually decides.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “At a minimum, the fitness of a particular parent cannot be judged without a consideration of that parent’s willingness and ability to care for the child, as well as the effect on a child of being placed in the custody of that parent. One who is fit to parent in some circumstances may not be fit if the circumstances are otherwise. A parent may be fit to raise one child but not another.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: A modification to grant Mother primary physical custody, while preserving meaningful and frequent parenting time for Father in settings and durations that can be safely managed in light of his condition, will better protect Samantha’s physical safety, emotional well‑being, and developmental needs, as contemplated by G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); and *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 56A.proposition: The Court enter any additional orders necessary to implement a safe and appropriate parenting plan, including, if needed, the appointment of a Guardian ad Litem or other professional to evaluate the child’s best interests, pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 56A and related authority.
